properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Southwesterly wind with gusts near 90 km/h tonight. Very strong southwesterly winds with gusts near 90 km/h have developed due to a cold front. These damaging winds will persist into the overnight hours before before veering to the west or northwest as they diminish. The highest wind gusts will be along exposed areas of the Lake Ontario shoreline. Power outages are possible. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-28T17:09:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-28T03:33:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2343546151.2019
Area: Picton - Sandbanks Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-29T08:26:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-28T16:26:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2856468786.2019
Area: Matane, Grande-Vall√©e area, Sainte-Anne-des-Monts area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Southwesterly winds with gusts to 80 km/h tonight. Strong southwesterly winds gusting to 80 km/h have developed in the wake of a sharp cold front blasting through Eastern Ontario. The strongest wind gusts will be along exposed areas of the Lake Ontario shoreline. Winds will veer to the west overnight and then become northwesterly in the morning as they diminish. Strong winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Isolated power outages are also possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-28T17:14:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-28T03:31:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0717552042.2019
Area: Belleville - Quinte West - Eastern Northumberland County, Cobourg - Colborne - Western Northumberland County, Kingston - Odessa - Frontenac Islands, Napanee - Consecon

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Southwesterly winds gusting to 100 km/h late this evening and gusting to 90 km/h overnight. The winds will remain southwesterly until Thursday morning and then shift to northwesterly as they diminish. The highest wind gusts will be in exposed areas along the Lake Erie shore. Power outages are possible. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-28T17:09:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-28T03:28:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2377189247.2019

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Significant snowfall will continue this morning. An additional 2 to 4 centimetres is expected today. Snow will become light this afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-28T21:59:09-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall, followed by significant rainfall, is expected. Total snowfall: 2 to 4 cm, except 10 cm inland and over higher terrain. Total rainfall: 30 to 50 mm. Locations: Avalon and Burin Peninsulas. Time span: early Friday morning until Saturday afternoon. Remarks: Drizzle will transition to wet snow early in the morning on Friday. The snow may be heavy at times, especially over higher terrain, but will then change to rain, at times heavy, later Friday morning. The rain is expected to ease to drizzle or showers Friday afternoon, but periods of rain will likely redevelop Friday night. Wet weather will then continue into Saturday. Motorists are advised to be prepared for winter driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-29T06:19:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-28T14:20:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2522986745.2019

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. Locations: Gander to Clarenville. Time span: Friday morning until late Friday afternoon. Remarks: Drizzle will transition to a period of heavy, wet snow on Friday morning, before changing back to drizzle or rain showers later in the day or early Friday night. Accumulations will be variable, with the highest amounts occurring inland and over elevated terrain. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. Locations: Postville to Makkovik Time span: today through Sunday. Remarks: Snow mixed with rain will change to snow this evening and will persist on Friday. Strong winds will cause blowing snow over exposed areas. Significant snowfall amounts will continue from Friday night to Sunday due to another incoming low pressure system. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-29T06:53:41-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain and some accumulating snow for today. Total rainfall: 20 to 40 mm, with locally higher amounts possible. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm, mainly inland and over higher terrain. Locations: mainland Nova Scotia. Time span: Until this evening. Remarks: Rain is expected to persist for much of the day, but will be mixed with or change to snow over inland areas and especially over higher terrain. Precipitation will gradually end this evening. In addition, strong northeasterly winds gusting to 80 km/h will persist this afternoon and then become northerly this evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-29T03:59:26-00:00

properties.Summary:
Description: Accumulating snow is expected. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm, with locally higher amounts possible. Locations: northeast coast of Newfoundland. Time span: Friday morning until Friday afternoon. Remarks: Drizzle will transition to a mixture of snow and rain Friday morning before turning back to showers or drizzle later in the day or early Friday night. Snowfall accumulations will be variable, with the highest accumulations likely occurring inland and over elevated terrain. Motorists are advised to be prepared for winter driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant amounts of precipitation are expected. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm inland and over over higher terrain. Total rainfall: 30 to 50 mm along the coast. Locations: Burgeo area to the Connaigre Peninsula. Time span: Friday morning until Saturday evening. Remarks: A mixture of precipitation will develop Friday morning, with mainly rain along the coast and snow inland and over higher elevations. Precipitation will transition to rain over all areas Friday morning and continue into Saturday while gradually tapering off. Motorists are advised to be prepared for winter driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant high elevation snowfall is expected. Total snowfall: 30 to 50 cm over the Long Range Mountains. Lesser amounts elsewhere. Locations: western and northern Newfoundland. Time span: Friday afternoon until Sunday morning. Remarks: A prolonged period of high-elevation snowfall is expected beginning Friday afternoon and continuing into the weekend. While precipitation will fall as a mixture of snow and rain over the lower elevations near the coast, snow will be dominant over mountainous areas. Motorists should be prepared for winter driving conditions, especially over higher terrain. Anyone planning to use backcountry trails should be prepared for large amounts of snowfall. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-29T06:20:50-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential for significant snowfall and strong winds Friday night through Sunday morning. Locations: along the coast from L'Anse-au-Clair to Hopedale and inland to Upper Lake Melville. Snowfall totals: possibly 15 to 30 cm. Time span: beginning Friday night and ending overnight Saturday night or Sunday. Remarks: Periods of rain, drizzle and snow are expected to continue along the Labrador coast today and Friday. On Friday night, the precipitation will intensify. Generally snow is expected inland while coastal areas of southeastern Labrador may see some mixing with rain. It is too soon to accurately predict snowfall totals but at this time, it appears the heaviest accumulations will occur north of the Straits area. A snowfall warning has been issued for Postville to Makkovik for a separate system currently affecting the area. Peak wind gusts: Possibly 90 to 120 km/h. Time span: Saturday morning to Sunday morning. Remarks: Winds will strengthen out of the northeast on Friday night and potentially reach warning criteria by early Saturday. Strong wind gusts will continue and gradually shift to northwesterly by Saturday night. Coastal areas will have the greatest chance of seeing the strongest wind gusts. Specific locations for strongest gusts will be provided in subsequent forecasts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-29T06:55:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-28T14:56:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3498765940.2019
Area: Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair, Norman Bay to Lodge Bay, Cartwright to Black Tickle, Rigolet and vicinity, Postville - Makkovik, Hopedale and vicinity, Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A prolonged period of snow continues for southern Alberta. An additional 5 to 10 centimetres is expected Thursday. Gusty northerly winds are producing near zero visibilities in blowing snow in open areas. The heavy snow will taper off this evening. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-29T02:59:52-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Accumulating snow expected, except rain along Fundy coast. Total snowfall: 5 to 15 cm. Locations: southern New Brunswick Time span: This afternoon. Remarks: Snow is expected to continue until this afternoon when it will taper to showers or flurries. The greatest snowfall accumulations are expected over the areas between St. Stephen and Sussex. General snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are expected with a possibility of up to 15 cm over higher terrain. Rain will prevail near the Fundy coast with additional amounts of 5 mm expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
